1. The Negroes in Jamaica are still driven at their work by the impulse of the carl-whip, as cattle or horses are driven in this country. - This fact is undeniable. But let us only consider for one moment all the depressing and brutalizing side effects of such a system, - a system which shuts out the Negro from even the pretence to a higher motive for exertion than the fear of the lash, and which extracts labour from him, not in the measure which his strength affords, or his interest prompts , but in the measure which an overseer or a driver may choose to draw from him by impending terror or the actual infliction of corporal punishment; - let us only consider this one feature of coloniad bondage, and we shall at once see enough to account for more than half od its multiplied evils.*
* The following description of the driving system has been given by one who was long an eye-witness of its practical operation. It is contained in a pamphlet, publishes by Hatchard in 1802, entitled "The Crisis of the Sugar Colonies."(p.8-13.)
"That West India Slaves, whether French or English, are the property of their master, and transferable by him, like his inanimate effects; that in general he is absolute ariter of the extent and the mode of their labout, and of the quantity of subsistence to be given in return for it; and that they are disciplined and punished at his discretion, direct privation of life or member excepted : these are prominent features, and sufficiently known, of the state of slavery. Not is the manner in which the labour of the slaves is conducted a matter of less publicity. Everyman who has heard any thing of West Indian affairs, is aquainted with the term Negro-drivers, and knows, or may know, that the slaves, in their ordinary field-labours, are driven to their work, in the strict sense of the term 'driven' is used in Europe: though this statemnt no more involves an intimation, that, in practice, the lash is incessantly, or with any needless frequency, applied to their back , then the phrase 'to drive a team of horses' imports, that the waggoner is continually smacking his whip.
